title: The Endomembrane System
moduleTitle: Cells as the Basis of Life
description: Tracing the pathway of proteins from synthesis to export through the endomembrane system, including rough and smooth ER, and the Golgi apparatus.
learningIntentions: Students can trace the pathway of a protein from synthesis to export through the endomembrane system.
Students can distinguish between rough ER (protein synthesis) and smooth ER (lipid synthesis/detox).
Students can describe the role of the Golgi apparatus in modifying, sorting, and packaging proteins.

engagementHook.title: The Cellular Production Line
engagementHook.content: 'Your pancreas makes insulin—a protein hormone that must be exported into the blood to control sugar. If the cell just released insulin immediately after making it, it wouldn't work properly. It needs folding, modification, and packaging. Today we follow the cellular production line from the factory floor (RER) to the shipping department (Golgi).'

keyConcepts.definition: A group of organelles (nuclear envelope, ER, Golgi, lysosomes, vesicles, plasma membrane) that work together to modify, package, and transport lipids and proteins.
Studded with ribosomes (80S). Synthesises proteins that are either inserted into membranes or exported from the cell. Continuous with the nuclear envelope.
No ribosomes. Synthesises lipids (including hormones), detoxifies drugs (in liver cells), and stores calcium ions (in muscle cells).
Small membrane sacs that move materials between ER and Golgi, and Golgi to other destinations.
Stack of flattened membranes (cisternae). Receives proteins from ER, modifies them (adds carbohydrates), sorts them, and packages them into vesicles for shipping to lysosomes or export from cell.

misconceptions.misconception: The Golgi just packages like a post office
misconceptions.correction: It also modifies proteins (adds carbohydrate groups), not just packages.

misconceptions.misconception: RER and SER are completely separate
misconceptions.correction: They are continuous with each other and the nuclear envelope.

misconceptions.misconception: All proteins go through the Golgi
misconceptions.correction: Only those destined for membranes, export, or lysosomes. Proteins for use in cytosol are made on free ribosomes and stay in cytoplasm.

contentSections.title: The Endomembrane System Pathway
contentSections.content: Flow diagram: Nuclear envelope → RER → Transport vesicle → Golgi (cis to trans) → Secretory vesicle → Plasma membrane (exocytosis).
keyPoints: RER makes proteins → vesicle to Golgi
Golgi modifies and sorts → vesicle to destination
Secretory vesicles fuse with plasma membrane for export
contentSections.example: I-cell disease: Failure to add 'address label' (mannose-6-phosphate) to enzymes → enzymes shipped out instead of going to lysosomes → disease symptoms.

contentSections.title: Rough vs Smooth ER

items: Abundant in cells making secretory proteins (pancreas)
Abundant in liver (detox) and muscle (Ca²⁺ storage)

contentSections.example: Liver cells have lots of SER to detoxify alcohol and drugs.

contentSections.title: The Golgi Modification Centre
contentSections.content: Proteins arrive from ER in vesicles. Golgi modifies proteins (adds carbohydrate groups—glycoproteins), sorts them (uses molecular 'zip codes'), packages them into new vesicles. Some go to lysosomes, some to plasma membrane for export.
contentSections.example: Processing of digestive enzymes in pancreatic cells—if Golgi fails, enzymes don't reach stomach.

multipleChoice.question: The rough endoplasmic reticulum is described as 'rough' because it:
options: Has a bumpy appearance under the microscope due to ribosomes attached to its surface
multipleChoice.correctAnswer: Has a bumpy appearance under the microscope due to ribosomes attached to its surface
multipleChoice.rationale: Tests structural basis of name. The ribosomes attached to the cytosolic surface give it a rough appearance in electron micrographs.

multipleChoice.question: Which organelle modifies, sorts, and packages proteins for secretion?
multipleChoice.rationale: Core Golgi function. Nucleus stores DNA; ribosomes synthesise proteins; mitochondria produce ATP.

multipleChoice.question: Proteins destined for export from the cell are synthesised on ribosomes attached to the:
multipleChoice.rationale: RER role in secretory protein synthesis. Smooth ER makes lipids; nucleolus makes ribosomes; mitochondria do cellular respiration.

shortAnswer.question: Outline the pathway of a secretory protein (such as a digestive enzyme) from synthesis to release from the cell, naming the organelles involved. (3 marks)
markingCriteria: 1 mark: Synthesised on ribosomes attached to rough ER (enters RER lumen)
1 mark: Transported via vesicles to Golgi apparatus (where modified/sorted)
1 mark: Packaged into secretory vesicles and released/exocytosed from plasma membrane
shortAnswer.commonError: Mentioning nucleus (transcription, not translation) or missing Golgi step.

shortAnswer.question: Distinguish between the rough endoplasmic reticulum and the smooth endoplasmic reticulum in terms of structure and function. (2 marks)
markingCriteria: 1 mark: RER has ribosomes attached and is involved in protein synthesis; SER lacks ribosomes
1 mark: SER is involved in lipid synthesis and/or detoxification (or Ca²⁺ storage in muscle)
shortAnswer.commonError: Stating RER makes lipids or SER makes proteins.

definitions: The endomembrane system includes the ER, Golgi, vesicles, and nuclear envelope.
Rough ER has ribosomes attached and makes proteins for export or membranes.
Smooth ER makes lipids and detoxifies chemicals (e.g., in liver).
The Golgi apparatus modifies, sorts, and packages proteins into vesicles.
Transport vesicles move materials between organelles.
keyPoints: Pathway: RER → vesicle → Golgi → vesicle → export
Golgi modifies (adds sugars), sorts (zip codes), packages

shortAnswer: A secretory protein is synthesised on ribosomes attached to the rough endoplasmic reticulum (RER) and enters the RER lumen for folding. It is then transported via vesicles to the Golgi apparatus, where it is modified and sorted. Finally, it is packaged into secretory vesicles that move to the plasma membrane and release the protein outside the cell through exocytosis.

The rough endoplasmic reticulum has ribosomes attached to its surface and is involved in protein synthesis and folding. The smooth endoplasmic reticulum lacks ribosomes and is involved in lipid synthesis, detoxification of drugs and poisons (particularly in liver cells), and calcium ion storage (in muscle cells).
